DataElement.preferredName: Stereotactic Radiosurgery Therapy First Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Administered Date
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the date that stereotactic radiosurgery was administered to the first brain lesion.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Stereotactic Radiosurgery Therapy First Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Administered
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to stereotactic radiosurgery, high-dose radiation is administered through openings in the head frame to the tumor while decreasing the amount of radiation given to normal brain tissue, administered as therapy to the first neoplasm from a primary site to the brain.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: (STAIR-ee-o-TAK-tik...) A radiation therapy technique involving a rigid head frame that is attached to the skull; high-dose radiation is administered through openings in the head frame to the tumor while decreasing the amount of radiation given to normal brain tissue. This procedure does not involve surgery.:An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Concepts.definition: A non-surgical procedure that was developed to deliver one or several maximum dose targeted radiation treatments for cancers in the brain or spine.
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Property.preferredName: First Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Administered
Property.preferredDefinition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.:The spread of a neoplasm from a primary site to the brain. The most common primary tumors metastatic to brain include lung cancer(adenosquamous and small cell especially), breast cancer, melanoma, renal cancer and colon cancer. Metastases are frequently found at the grey/white junction. They are usually well demarcated from the brain parenchyma. The majority of metastases (greater than 75%) are found supratentorially with the minority (less than 10%) found in the brainstem. The patients present with signs and symptoms referable to either increased intracranial pressure or focal pathology. A contrast enhanced MRI will give the best view of suspected metastatic cancers. Therapy for the metastatic cancer is based upon the therapy that would be or has been given to the primary cancer. In any event corticosteroids can be useful for reduction of patients' symptoms. (Kaye, Laws Brain Tumors Churchill Livingstone 1995):Given.

Concepts.definition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.

Concepts.longName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Brain
Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread to the brain from another anatomic site or system. The majority are carcinomas (usually lung or breast carcinomas).
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The date on which an observation was made or an event occurred.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: a particular day specified as the time something has, or will, happen.

Concepts.definition: The particular day, month and year an event has happened or will happen.
